description: From Latin con- (prefix indicating a being or bringing together of several objects) + saliō (“to bound, jump, leap”) (modelled after resiliēns (“rebounding”))  +‎ -ence, influenced by concurrent. Coined by English polymath William Whewell in 1840 in his book The Philosophy of the Inductive Sciences.

entries.meaning: (logic) The concurrence of multiple inductions drawn from different data sets. [from 1840]
The agreement, co-operation, or overlap of academic disciplines.
